paragraphs.content: Switch statements are similiar to if-else statements in that they allow for specific blocks of code to executed based on whether a specific 'case' (condition) is true or false.

trueFalseQuiz.question: True or false: Switch statements are the same as if statements.
trueFalseQuiz.feedbackRight: Correct! Switch statements and if statements are completely different even though they have some similarities in the way they function. This will be discussed further into the topic.
trueFalseQuiz.feedbackWrong: Wrong! Switch statements and if statements are completely different even though they have some similarities in the way they function. This will be discussed further into the topic.

paragraphs.subheading: How to create a switch statement
paragraphs.content: The example below shows how to create a switch statement. The switch statement specifies a condition (in the brackets) which the switch is based upon. It then specifies multiple 'cases' in which the result of the expression is compared with the value in the cases. If the case matches to the switch expression, the block of code in the case statement is executed.

images.caption: 'A flowchart demonstrating how a switch statement works (Source: https://www.programiz.com/c-programming/c-switch-case-statement)'

trueFalseQuiz.question: True or false: A switch statement is better than a if statement for situations when there are many possible cases.
trueFalseQuiz.feedbackRight: Correct! Switch statements are better because cases are simpler to write and cases are traversed more efficiently.
trueFalseQuiz.feedbackWrong: Wrong! Switch statements are better because cases are simpler to write and cases are traversed more efficiently.

paragraphs.content: The break keyword is implemented into the switch block and serves the function to exit the switch block when specified. This ensures that no other cases are checked.

images.caption: 'An example of a break statement within a case'

paragraphs.content: The default keyword is implemented into the switch block and is just like the else statement in an if-else block; it specifies a block of code to be run when no other case has been matched.

images.caption: 'An example of a switch statement with a default case if no other cases match'
